title: Induced emf - data on time-varying magnetic field

content.question: A circular coil of wire with <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math> loops and an area of <math alttext="0.25 square meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.25</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> lies so the plane of the loop is perpendicular to a time-varying magnetic field <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math>. The magnetic field strength <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> is shown in the graph. Which of the following correctly describes the induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> in the loop for the time interval shown in the graph and provides the correct justification?

choices.label: The induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> in the loop is constant and non-zero because the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> is proportional to the change in the magnetic field which is constant and non-zero.

The induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> in the loop is constant and non-zero because the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> is proportional to the area of the loop which remains constant.

The induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> in the loop increases because the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> is proportional to the magnetic field which increases.

The induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> in the loop increases because the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> increases with each of the <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math> loops of wire.

content.answer: The induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> in the loop is constant and non-zero because the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> is proportional to the change in the magnetic field which is constant and non-zero.
